newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - US T-bond futures seen hesitant near term.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - US T-bond futures seen hesitant near term.

text.p: U.S. Treasury bond futures are likely to be hesitant to make big moves in either direction in the near term, technical analysts said.

Dan Busiel, a vice president at First Chicago Futures, said the bounce in June T-bond futures from early lows this morning could be a sign the market's widely anticipated correction to last week's gains might be a slow process.
"I did anticipate we'd have another move down to the 108 handle, but now I'm starting to doubt because today's price action has been pretty good," he said.
June T-bonds were up 6/32 at 109-16/32 in late morning trade after dipping to a low of 108-30/43 earlier.

Still, Busiel said he expected the contract to test 108-11/32 before probing new highs, possibly on a friendly reading in next week's retail sales and inflation data. The 108-11/32 support represented the 50-percent retracement of the rise from the April 11 bottom of 106-12/32 to last Friday's 110-10/32 high.
Overall, Busiel said the market should have a slightly positive bias going into the May 20 Federal Open Market Committee meeting.
Stewart Taylor, president of Taylor Consulting, saw a slightly negative bias, although he also expected the relatively narrow seesaw trading to continue for a while.
He said the underlying trend was still down and that a recent buildup in open interest at higher levels would probably be a drag.
For the next few days, however, he said he would tend to be a buyer on weakness toward support at 108-26/32 to 109-00 and a seller on bounces toward the 109-29/32 area.
"The thing that concerns me the most is the general level of open interest," Taylor said.
"The big rise really leaves the market vulnerable...since most of the open interest was accrued when the market was moving higher," he added.

Open interest in June T-bond futures increased by 2,249 contracts to 487,389 on Wednesday, according to preliminary figures released by the CBOT. T-bond open interest for all months totalled 563,816 contracts at the end of Wednesday, up 1,475 on the day.
Taylor said the next major move would probably be to the downside but the market needed a catalyst to break out.
He said the "prime suspects" for such a catalyst were the Commodity Research Bureau index and the dollar.

The CRB index, up 1.06 point at 247.67 in late morning trade, has been behaving favorably for bonds lately, he said, but the dollar may have put in a top with its weakness this week after a two-year uptrend.
